title: Tuesday, 17th July, 2018

11:08 am

Okay, so it's summer. Officially.

VV75 morning

We continue to believe Greene King is a value trap.

11:14 am

Underlying trading remains poor, and profit is likely to go backwards again in FY 2018. Meanwhile, management’s debt refinancing appears to be destroying shareholder value in order to flatter the P&L.

......... really, really not keen.

BE11:15am

The argument here starts with the fact that we're in a golden period for pubs.

So .... Weather, football ........ uh, Royal Wedding? But Greene King only did 2.2% lfl growth for the first eight weeks

BE11:18am

Suggesting normalised LFL of zero or worse.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Even in one of the best periods for the pub trade in recent history, Greene King did not achieve adequate lfl growth to offset cost increases and grow earnings.

BE11:18am

But let's get onto the "destroying shareholder value" stuff.

Soundbuy Everybody's drinking craft gin in their attics...........
Lemmy Beers is coming home (retail in supermarkets > consumed on sofa)
BE11:19am

Management has talked up its refinancing of high interest rate bonds, which has reduced P&L interest and provided something of a shield for profitability. However, we think this is being disingenuous with shareholders. In reality, the refinancing of GBP279m of Spirit debt last year cost an “exceptional” cash amount of nearly GBP50m. Management refused to tell us the interest rate on its new GBP350m RCF used to fund the refinancing. However, we would have to assume it is less than 2.5% for the refinancing to have created any value. Given even the company’s cheapest secured debt costs c4%, we consider it more likely that it has destroyed cGBP25m-30m of value

Grouchmonkey @shrink - no thanks - bought at £13 sold at
11:19 am
BE11:19am

So ........... to the divi.

Upaswellasdown Morning. Would need to read the note but the comment on debt suggests that Berenberg don't understand the reality of being overleveraged / constrained by WBS
BE11:19am

Alongside the optical P&L improvement, we believe the real motivations for refinancing the Spirit debt may have been (1) to make the dividend cover look more favourable (and thus more sustainable), and (2) to remove debt securitisation on more pubs, allowing them to be sold. We think both of those are indicative of the challenging financial position Greene King is in now. With underlying trading still poor and leverage at 4.2x net debt/EBITDA, we struggle to see sense in the business continuing to pay GBP103m of dividends pa when it will only generate free cash flow of GBP50m-60m.

Grouchmonkey (continued due to non-standard character upsetting the system) less than £20 and can't believe where its got to now!

But it might be the lack of a Stranger Things or a House of Cards in the quarter.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

While management provided no specific explanation for the shortfall, content amortization growth slowed to 17% yoy, its lowest level since the launch of the streaming business. While certainly not a perfect proxy for content additions, either in quantity or quality, given the historic correlation between content investments and subscriber growth, we find the short fall in both numbers notable, particularly ahead of expected 2H growth acceleration in content amortization.

BE11:28am

Good graph:

BE11:28am

Also good.

BE11:29am

BE11:30am

Which feels a wee bit obvious, in retrospect. To sell subscriptions you need to have stuff to watch.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Here's JP Morgan.

SoS Pity Greene King didn't stay as a great local brewery and had to follow the big is best mantra.
BE11:31am

2Q results show that NFLX will not build subscribers in a straight line, but rather that net adds can be lumpy as underlying strong secular growth can be impacted by adverse seasonality and sometimes pushed higher or lower by new content. NFLX's 2Q18 streaming net adds of 5.15M were 17% below guidance of 6.2M, coming in light in both US and International. NFLX noted that acquisition growth was slightly lower than projected—suggesting that churn was less of a factor— and we believe that seasonality and less breakout content (relative to 2Q17) also weighed. NFLX also guided 3Q18 net adds slightly lower Q/Q, from 5.15M in 2Q to 5.0M in 3Q, below expectations in the 6.0M-6.5M range.

BE11:31am

NFLX content is stronger into the back half, with early hits in India. 2Q was a solid content quarter w/Lost in Space and 2nd seasons of 13 Reasons Why, Marvel’s Luke Cage, La Casa de Papel (Money Heist), & GLOW, among others. But 2Q content did not have the impact of a breakout hit like the 1st season of 13 Reasons Why in 2Q17. Looking to 2H18, NFLX content is back-half weighted including OITNB S6, Ozark S2, HOC S6, & Narcos S4, among others. We are also encouraged by NFLX’s early content success in India w/original film Lust Stories (launched late 2Q), NFLX's 1st Indian original series Sacred Games (July 6), & Ghoul to be launched August 24. We believe these pieces of content can help drive WOM around NFLX and build the brand in India.

BornCynic @SoS - buy Shepherd Neame ?
11:31 am
BE11:32am

Well, yeah, okay. But if every new market needs a La Casa de Papel to pad out the US-centric shows it's going to be quite pricey.

BE11:32am

NFLX still figuring out right balance of content spend & marketing. NFLX
remains on track for P&L content spend of close to $8B (cash ~$12B-$13B) & marketing spend of ~$2B in 2018. We believe 2018 is still a learning year as NFLX does marketing at a bigger scale, w/the total budget up ~60%. NFLX noted that 80-85% of marketing spend goes toward content titles & brand, while 15-20% goes toward direct acquisition. FX will push NFLX toward the lower half of its 10-11% operating margin range in 2018, but we still expect the company to increase both content & marketing spend over the next few years while delivering steadily higher operating margins.

Airborne Cigar @SoS - but someone else did and is still a great local brewery, when Greene King took that dark-side niche - we hope...
BE11:33am

Anyway, we can do the knife catching stuff for anyone who wants their confidence fortified.

11:33 am

Stifel provides .....

BE11:34am

we view Netflix’s long-term outlook positively, given the upside case we believe exists for the company’s domestic and international opportunities. Given the short-term sub add volatility leading to a pullback of shares in the aftermarket, we upgrade shares of Netflix to Buy from Hold as we believe shares are again at an attractive entry point.

BE11:35am

You could argue that 12 times revenue's enough to pay for a company with annual FCF burn of $3bn to $4bn.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Or you could look at the bigger picture ......

BE11:36am

With the potential for near-term sub add expectations to reset, a strong 2H content slate, and a domestic and international runway which supports a doubling of the company’s subscriber base in the next five to ten years, we are upgrading shares of NFLX to Buy from Hold, with a Target Price
of $406.

Grouchmonkey Actually scrap the request for Scapa - it's very dull. More to discuss in RMG perhaps
BE11:36am

BMO ditto.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

While re-rating again as it has over the past year+ is likely not in
the cards, we believe positions can be built at these levels (-14% after hours) as incremental investment points enter the story, including 1) we expect the India (and Japan) growth stories to build into 2019, 2) we expect NFLX to continue to transition to more originals from licensed studio content well, and 3) small but steady growth of consumer product licensing (and potentially other) revenue can create a more dynamic company over time. We have upgraded NFLX to Outperform.

BornCynic @Grouchmonkey - RMG = Royal Mail Group?
Sails @Airborne - Hall & Woodhouse? Adnams?
patatbat what does content amortisation growth mean?
BE11:38am

And the counterpoint from B Riley, which I think was predicting weak figures a week or so ago.

BE11:38am

We have argued in the past that Netflix is doing what no one else has—
generating much more impactful content year after year. Other content creators have dry spells. Netflix has not seen that yet. It is possible that after huge successes that Netflix's ability to create hit new shows may be settling into a robust plateau. Netflix would argue that this could influence quarterly results, but that its full-year growth will be driven by the deep library. That assertion has yet to be tested, because Netflix has not yet had a sustained dry spell for impactful new content. If that happens, we suspect that sub growth would be impacted. At an EV of 86X 2018E EBITDA and a P/E near 140x, the risk of that is enough to keep us from chasing the stock of this solidly performing company.

Grouchmonkey A Born Cynic. Yes. Sorry for lapsing into EPIC codes
BE11:41am

Jefferies can summarise so I don't have to.

BE11:41am

1Q18/19 underlying revenues increased by 2%, with UKPIL down 1% and GLS up 11%. Addressed letter volume decreased by 6% (vs. JEFe less than 6%), while revenues fell 7%, but by 5% excl. last year's election effects, implying a 1% price & mix effect, with price increases offset by downtrading. Parcel volume growth of 7% is ahead of FY18/19E guidance of c5%, incl. 2% points from cross-border, partly offset by a negative price & mix effect of 1%. GLS volume increased by 10% and revenues by 11%, in line with expectations. For FY18/19E, Royal Mail confirms guidance, with an addressed letter volume decline at the high-end of the 4%-6% guidance range or worse, related to GDPR uncertainty range, while parcel volume and revenue are expected to increase in line with FY17/18. FY18/19E consensus EBIT has recently come down by 7% and is expected to remain broadly unchanged.

BornCynic @Grouchmonkey - no problem, no need to apologise, glad I got it right.
11:42 am
BE11:42am

Or Morgan Stanley, if you like. Though you'll quickly detect a theme of the brokers not finding anything to say here.

BE11:42am

Underlying (excluding currency & acquisitions) group revenue growth was +2% for the quarter, a similar performance to the exit rates of the FY in March (group revenue +2% YoY). The mix remains skewed, with UK PIL revenue down 1% YoY, driven by UK Letters -7% (vols -6%) and offset partially by UK Parcels revenue growth of +6% (vols +7%). In the GLS business, revenue growth (ex currency) was +11% YoY vs FY17 exit rate of +10% (ex working day, revenue was up 10%, vols up 9%). GLS called out Italy, Denmark and Spain, with work continuing in US to integrate GSO and Postal Express. RMG comment that the 1Q18 trading performance was in line with expectation, with outlook for UK letters (down at weaker end of -4-6%) and parcel trends (+6%) unchanged for the FY19 and the cost avoidance target of £230m remains on track in UKPIL. Company does note that letter trend may fall outside range owing to GDPR & business uncertainty, while GLS margins may be impacted by labour market pressures. Consensus EBIT pre-transformation is at £654m vs MSe £679m (vs FY18 of £694m).

So ... why are they up 10%? Fair question. Other than Tosca and Dunstone's recent purchases feeding the speculation of a take-private, I can't really see much logic behind it.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:50am

TalkTalk has reported a 1Q19 trading update that shows clear headline momentum for broadband net adds and revenue growth, in line with the stated strategy and outlook. Within the mix the net adds are driven by FIholesale, churn did pick up very slightly on the 2 year anniversary of the new price plans, but ARpu for those recontracting is growing and the guidance for positive retail and wholesale net adds for the year has been re-iterated. On-net revenues rebounded strongly (when adjusting for IfRS15), and our earnings estimates are broadly unchanged.

While Paddy Power Betfair has significant first mover advantage in the US, we caution that, especially post the recent re-rating, it is very much a long-term value driven strategy. We update our SoTP for the share buyback, JV investment and regulatory impacts. Our valuation falls by £5.60 to £80.10. Despite bookmaker-friendly gross win margins in Q218, we downgrade to SELL from Buy.
